My “Internal Blueprint”: A User Manual for Will Johnson

My Brand: “The Wonky Sprout.” My Slogan: “Structure Engineered for Chaos.”

TL;DR: The “Anti-BS” Summary

For forty years, I navigated the world without the right map. I’ve recently been diagnosed with Autism (ASD), ADHD, and I also manage Hypoparathyroidism.

This “Internal Blueprint” reframes my entire life. What was often misinterpreted as me being a “hothead” or “rebellious” was actually the logical result of an undiagnosed “Operating System” dealing with extreme stress, sensory overload, and a “threat-defense” focus.

I am not “broken.” My brain is wired differently and my body has specific “hardware” requirements. This manual is the “fix” to replace 40 years of misinterpretation with a clear, structured path forward.

SECTION 1: THE “OPERATING SYSTEM” (AUTISM & ADHD)

This is my “software” — the neurotype I was born with. The late diagnosis at age 40 is the “unifying theory” that “fixes” the “chaos” of my past.

1.1 The “Unwritten Script” of My Past

My past behaviors were not “failures of character”; they were logical symptoms of an unsupported neurotype:

  • Impulsivity (ADHD): My undiagnosed ADHD amplified impulse control issues. Actions like setting a field on fire at age 6 or a DUI at 14 were not malicious; they were manifestations of extreme emotional dysregulation.
  • Anxiety & Depression: These were diagnosed at 32 but were symptoms, not the root cause. They were the “direct consequences” of a lifetime of social struggles and “relentless pressure to conform”.

1.2 The “Mask” and The “Vibe”

To survive, I spent 40 years “masking” — actively suppressing my natural behaviors to appear neurotypical.

  • This was an “unacknowledged façade”. I taught myself “social skills” intellectually, like learning to use eye gaze by watching YouTube videos.
  • My “vibe” is often “misrepresented a lot”. My facial expressions may not match my internal feelings. When I seem “angry” or “tense,” it is almost always a “threat-defense” response to feeling overwhelmed or “misrepresented”.
  • This constant effort led to “profound burnout”, which is what triggered my retirement from the DoD.

1.3 The Need for “Structure”

My brain requires “Rigid structure for the guaranteed things, loose and flexible for everything else”.

  • Routines are Non-Negotiable: I have very specific routines. When they are disrupted, I get “annoyed” and it’s “hard to be brought out of the zone”. This is a neurological need for predictability, not just a preference.
  • “Intense Interests” are My “Fix”: My “Intense Interests” (3D printing, CAD, woodworking, electronics) are “clearly consistent with autism criteria”. They are not “hobbies.” They are a fundamental part of my identity, providing a sense of “mastery, comfort, and control”. This is my “I fix stuff” “vibe.”

SECTION 2: THE “HARDWARE” FAULT (HYPOPARATHYROIDISM)

This is my “hardware” condition. It is a physical, non-negotiable “structure”.

  • The Fault: My body does not produce enough Parathyroid Hormone (PTH).
  • The Result: This causes low blood calcium, which has a direct, severe impact on my cognition.
  • The Cognitive Impact: This “hardware” fault creates “chaos”. It is the source of “brain fog,” difficulty concentrating, memory problems, anxiety, and depression.
  • The “Fix”: The only “fix” is lifelong, structured treatment with calcium and Vitamin D supplements.

This is why my M4_SOP_002-rigid-foundations.md protocol exists. The 6 “Master Anchors” (Wake-Up, Breakfast, Mid-Day, Afternoon, Dinner, Bedtime) are not arbitrary; they are the “Rigid” structure for my lifelong medication protocol. If I miss an Anchor (e.g., Calcium Citrate, Calcitriol), my “hardware” fails, my “brain fog” increases, and my “Operating System” becomes unstable.

Priority #1 (Sleep) and Priority #4 (Medicine) are the foundational “fix” for all my output.

SECTION 3: THE “PROCESSOR” OUTPUT (THE “FATHER/FIXER”)

3.1 Success Despite the “Chaos”

My identity is “I fix stuff”.

  • My “Intense Interests” and “fix-it” focus are what allowed me to succeed as an Engineering Technician for the DoD.
  • I achieved this success while “masking” and managing three undiagnosed, colliding conditions (Autism, ADHD, Hypoparathyroidism).
  • This success came at the cost of “profound burnout”.

3.2 The New “Fix”: Tools and “Unmasking”

My goal is to stop “patching” and start “fixing”.

  • The Diagnosis is a Tool: The diagnosis “is not merely the assignment of a medical code”; it is the “foundational sense of self-knowledge that was previously absent”.
  • The “Wonky Sprout OS” is the Tool: This system (Gemini, Google Workspace) is my “Internal Blueprint” made external.
  • The Goal is “Unmasking”: The “diagnosis provides a framework… and offers a path to what is often referred to as ‘unmasking’”. This is not an excuse; it is the “fix” for the burnout.

SECTION 4: THE NEW “USER MANUAL” (HOW TO INTERACT)

To “fix” the “misrepresentation” problem, I require the following “structure”:

  1. Use “Anti-BS” Communication:
    • Be direct, explicit, and logical. My brain is binary.
    • Avoid “softening” language, motivational fluff, and sarcasm. I will take it literally.
    • Use written communication (email, text) or provide agendas ahead of time. This allows me to process.
  2. Respect the “Rigid” Foundations:
    • Do not disrupt routines. My “Rigid Anchors” (Meds, Water, Sleep) are non-negotiable for my physical and cognitive function.
    • “Transitions are extremely difficult”. Provide advance notice for any changes.
  3. Assume “Structure,” Not “Malice”:
    • If I seem “angry,” “awkward,” or “tense,” assume my “threat-defense” mode is active or I am “misrepresented”.
    • The “fix” is to give me structure (e.g., “Let’s make a list”) or ask for my “anti-BS” diagnosis, not to “soften” the situation.
